TEXT: The applicant is a NORP national , born in DATE and living in LOC region . He is represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE the applicant was arrested on suspicion of the unlawful possession of a hunting knife , in breach of Article CARDINAL of LAW . On DATE GPE found inter alia that the knife was PERSON and could be considered to be a weapon for the purpose of that provision . The court ordered the applicant ’s detention on remand for the alleged offence under LAW on the grounds of his serious criminal record , his unemployment and a risk that he might commit new offences , within the meaning to LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW . His remand in custody was authorised until DATE . The applicant and his defence counsel were present in court .

The applicant appealed against the detention order , asserting that there were no reasons for holding him in custody . He stated in particular that there was no danger of his committing new offences .

On DATE ORG held the appeal hearing in the presence of the applicant ’s defence counsel . ORG dismissed the appeal , finding that there was a reasonable suspicion that the applicant had committed an offence . The court held that ORG had erred in detaining the applicant under LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW as he had not been suspected of having committed any offence listed in paragraph CARDINAL of that provision . ORG found no reason to suspect that the applicant might commit any new offence envisaged by LAW ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW . However , it ruled that these errors were not of such a nature or degree as to render the applicant ’s detention unlawful . By reference to the fact that the applicant had misled the authorities concerning the question of his address and that he had no permanent place of residence , ORG also held that there was a danger of his absconding , thereby justifying his detention under LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW .

On DATE the Palanga City District Court extended the term of the applicant ’s remand in custody to DATE , emphasising the danger of his absconding , given the applicant ’s contradictions about his place of residence . The applicant and his representatives were present in court .

The applicant appealed , claiming that there was no danger of his absconding that the case - file contained no proper evidence of his guilt , and that the alleged offence alleged was minor . He requested ORG to quash the decision of DATE and to release him . On DATE ORG , in the presence of the applicant ’s defence counsel , rejected the appeal as unsubstantiated .

On DATE GPE extended the term of the applicant ’s remand in custody to DATE , finding that there was a danger of his absconding , given the applicant ’s contradictions about his place of residence . The applicant and his defence counsel were present in court .

On DATE the Palanga City District Court convicted the applicant of the unlawful possession of a weapon under Article CARDINAL of LAW . He was given a prison sentence of DATE , which was deemed served on account of the time spent in detention on remand . He was released in the courtroom .
The applicant did not appeal against that judgment .
Relevant provisions of LAW ( NORP kodeksas ) :

Article CARDINAL of the Criminal Code provides that a person may be punished with a sentence of up to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment for the unlawful possession , production or sale of weapons specifically made to kill or inflict bodily harm , including hunting knives .
Relevant provisions of LAW ( ORG proceso kodeksas ) :
Article CARDINAL :
“ No one shall be arrested or detained save by virtue of a decision of a court or judge . ”

Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL LAW provide that the accused and their counsel have the right to submit requests and appeal against acts and decisions of an interrogator , investigator , prosecutor or court .
Article CARDINAL :
“ Detention on remand shall be used only … in cases where a statutory penalty of DATE imprisonment is envisaged . … .
The grounds for the detention on remand shall be the reasoned suspicion that the accused will :
( CARDINAL ) abscond from the investigation and trial ;
( CARDINAL ) obstruct the determination of the truth in the case ;
( CARDINAL ) commit new offences … whilst suspected of having committed crimes . ”
Article CARDINAL - CARDINAL :

“ … the arrested person shall be brought before a judge within not more than TIME . The judge must hear the person as to the grounds of the arrest . The prosecutor and defence counsel must take part in the inquiry , unless the judge decides otherwise . After having questioned the arrested person , the judge may maintain the arrest order by designating the specific term of detention , or vary or revoke the remand … .
After the case has been transmitted to the court … [ it ] can order , vary or revoke the detention on remand . The court shall extend the detention on remand before its expiry . ”
Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( in force from DATE until DATE ) :

“ For the purpose of extending the term of detention on remand a judge … must convene a hearing to which defence counsel , the prosecutor and the detainee , the presence of whom is obligatory , shall be called . The judge decides whether or not to extend the term of detention on remand . … . ”

Article CARDINAL - CARDINAL provides for an appeal to a higher court and a hearing against a decision ordering or extending the term of detention both at the stage of pre - trial investigation and trial , in the presence of the detainee and his defence counsel , or only counsel . If the appellate court finds procedural irregularities that do not affect the essence of the detention order , the court must eliminate the defects without quashing the order .

Pursuant to the general provision of LAW , a first instance decision , including remand decisions , was not effective pending the time - limit for an appeal against that decision or during the appeal proceedings . The present LAW ( version in force from DATE ) specifies that all decisions of detention on remand become effective and are executed on the date when they are taken .
